questions.text: A patient presents with photophobia and redness of the eye. On examination, vertically oval and mid-dilated pupils are seen. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.correct_answer: B. Acute congestive / angle closure glaucoma
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Acute congestive / angle closure glaucoma Classically , patients are elderly , suffer from hyperopia , and have no history of glaucoma . Most commonly, they present with periorbital pain and visual deficits . The pain is boring in nature and associated with an ipsilateral headache . Patients note blurry vision and describe the phenomenon of " seeing halos around objects ." Careful investigation may elucidate a precipitating factor , such as dim light or medications (e.g., anticholinergics, sympathomimetics). In a large percentage of patients, extraocular symptoms and systemic manifestations are the chief complaints.

Highyeild:

Patients present with headaches and may receive medications for migraines or an evaluation for a subarachnoid haemorrhage .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A . Acute retrobulbar neuritis: Retrobulbar neuritis is a form of optic neuritis in which the optic nerve, which is at the back of the eye, becomes inflamed . The inflamed area is between the back of the eye and the brain. The optic nerve contains fibres that carry visual information from the nerve cells in the retina to the nerve cells in the brain. Option C . Acute anterior uveitis: Acute anterior uveitis is characterised by an extremely painful red eye , often associated with photophobia , and occasionally with decreased visual acuity . Chronic anterior uveitis is defined as inflammation lasting over 6 weeks . It is usually asymptomatic , but many people have mild symptoms during exacerbations. Option D . Severe Keratoconjunctivitis: Keratoconjunctivitis refers to an inflammatory process that involves both the conjunctiva (conjunctivitis) and the superficial cornea (keratitis) which can occur in association with viral, bacterial, autoimmune, toxic, and allergic aetiologies.

Extraedge:

Several case reports discuss patients presenting with vomiting and abdominal pain who were misdiagnosed with gastroenteritis.

questions.text: The treatment of choice in acute congestive glaucoma is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Laser iridotomy The treatment of choice for pupillary-block ACG is laser iridotomy. Iridectomy with an argon and/or Nd : YAG laser creates an opening in the iris through which aqueous humour trapped in the posterior chamber can reach the anterior chamber and trabecular meshwork. As aqueous humour flows into the anterior chamber through the iris defect, pressure behind the iris falls, allowing the iris to fall back towards its normal position.

Highyeild:

This procedure opens the anterior chamber angle and relieves the blockade of the trabecular meshwork . It also prevents future pupillary blocks and AAC.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . Pilocarpine: Pilocarpine is a medication used to reduce pressure inside the eye and treat dry mouth . As eye drops, they are used to manage angle closure glaucoma until surgery can be performed, ocular hypertension , primary open angle glaucoma, and to bring about constriction of the pupil following its dilation. Option: C . Timolol: Ophthalmic timolol is used to treat glaucoma , a condition in which increased pressure in the eye can lead to gradual loss of vision . Timolol is in a class of medications called beta - blockers . It works by decreasing the pressure in the eye. Option: D . Trabeculoplasty: Laser trabeculoplasty is a treatment for open - angle glaucoma . It uses laser light that is applied to the trabecular meshwork. The trabecular meshwork is an area made up of tiny channels where fluid drains from the eye.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is contraindicated in a patient with history of sulfa allergy presenting with an acute attack of angle closure glaucoma?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Acetazolamide Carbonic anhydrous inhibitors are the most potent and commonly used systemic anti glaucoma drugs. These include acetazolamide, methazolamide, dichlorphenamide and ethoxzolamide. MOA- They inhibit the enzyme CA, which is related to the process of aqueous production, thereby reducing IOP. Indications: all types of acute and chronic glaucoma.

Highyeild:

Side effects - Paresthesia of fingers, toes, hands, feet, and around the mouth Increased urinary frequency Serum electrolyte imbalance : bicarbonate depletion leading to metabolic acidosis GI symptoms like vague abdominal pain, gastric irritation, nausea, a peculiar metallic taste, and diarrhea Sulfonamide- related side effects like renal calculus, Steven Johnson syndrome , and transient myopia

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . Glycerol: Glycerol is a naturally occurring alcohol . It is an odourless liquid that is used as a solvent, sweetening agent, and medicine. When glycerol is in the intestines, it attracts water into the gut, softening stools and relieving constipation . Option: C Mannitol: Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic that is metabolically inert in humans and occurs naturally, as a sugar or sugar alcohol, in fruits and vegetables. Option: D Latanoprost: Latanoprost, sold under the brand name Xalatan, among others, is a medication used to treat increased pressure inside the eye. This includes ocular hypertension and open angle glaucoma . It is applied as eye drops to the eyes. The onset of effects is usually within four hours, and they last for up to a day.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient complains of a severe right sided headache and diminution of vision in her right eye for the few hours. She also complains of redness in her and nausea. She has no history of similar complaints in the past. Vitals are stable. On examination, the pupil is vertically oval and mid-dilated, along with a shallow anterior chamber. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Acute angle closure glaucoma This is a case of acute or congestive angle closure glaucoma, which is caused by a sudden occlusion of the iridocorneal angle with a resultant acute rise of intraocular pressure to extremely high levels. Patients complain of a severe unilateral headache and diminution of vision in the ‘red’eye. Nausea may be frequently associated. On examination, ciliary and conjunctival congestion, corneal oedema, a shallow anterior chamber and iris bombé with a vertically oval, mid-dilated pupil are present. After resolution of the corneal oedema, a gonioscopic ally closed angle can be seen, i.e. extensive iridocorneal synechiae, and the optic disc may be found to be either hyperaemic or normal.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B . A diagnosis of chronic primary angle closure glaucoma (PACG) is made if the intraocular pressure is chronically raised in eyes having synechial closure over at least 180° in an occludable angle. Changes in the optic nerve head and visual field should also be present. Repeated subacute attacks or acute attacks persisting for more than a few hours can cause chronic PACG. Since there is no past history of similar attacks and the present history is of short duration, it is a case of acute PACG. Option: C . Primary open angle glaucoma is generally asymptomatic, and patients may have nonspecific complaints such as headache, frequent changes in presbyopic correction, ‘blind spot’ or scotoma, especially in the inferior field, and difficulty in dark adaptation. They do not present acutely as in this case, and anterior chamber depth is normal in these cases. Option: D. Conjunctivitis presents with symptoms and signs of discomfort, foreign body sensation, photophobia, and discharge from the eyes (type of discharge depending on the cause), conjunctival congestion and chemosis i.e. swelling of conjunctiva. Pupillary changes and shallow anterior chambers are not found in conjunctivitis.

questions.text: A 37-year-old male patient presents with acute-onset redness of the left eye, diminution of vision and severe headache. He has no history of similar complaints in the past. On examination, the pupil is vertically oval and mid-dilated along with a shallow anterior chamber and raised IOP. What is the treatment of the condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Both B and C The given scenario depicts acute congestive glaucoma, which needs to be treated with topical and systemic medications. Raised IOP is controlled immediately with intravenous acetazolamide. 500 mg, and/or intravenous mannitol. These measures also relieve ischaemic changes in the iris and lead to a decrease in corneal oedema. Topical Pilocarpine 2% should be instituted to constrict the pupil and pull the iris away from the angle.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Since it is an acute condition, acetazolamide is administered via the intravenous route and not orally, at a dose of 500 mg.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a finding of acute angle closure glaucoma?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Constricted pupil A vertically oval, mid-dilated pupil is seen in cases of primary angle closure glaucoma (PACG).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A, B, and C: On examination of the glaucomatous eye, ciliary and conjunctival congestion, corneal oedema, shallow anterior chamber, and iris bombé may be seen, and after resolution of the corneal oedema, a gonioscopic ally closed angle can be seen with extensive iridocorneal synechiae.

questions.text: A 39-year-old presents with sudden diminution of vision of the right eye. On examination the eye is red and Iop is raised. Which of the following is not a risk factor for the development of the condition mentioned above?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Myopia A short eye is a risk factor for the development of acute congestive glaucoma, which is seen in this case. Unlike in myopia, where there is an increase in anteroposterior length of the eyeball.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B, C, and D. Anatomical factors predisposing to PACG are short eyes, smaller corneal diameter, a shallow anterior chamber, and relative anterior positioning of the lens–iris diaphragm. Other mechanisms For closure of the iridocorneal angle, these are three factors: plateau iris configuration, increased lens vault, and peripheral crowding of the iris.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man presents with redness of eye for 1 hour along with diminution of vision. He has known cases of diabetes for 5 years and on regular medications. There is no past history. What changes are seen in the image given below?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ciliary congestion This is a case of acute angle closure glaucoma. The image depicts ciliary congestion, a vertically oval, mid-dilated pupil, and glaucoma fleckes the lens.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. A vertically oval, mid-dilated pupil is seen in cases of acute angle closure glaucoma. Option: B . Vertical, deep stromal parallel striae known as Vogt's striae are seen in the later stages of keratoconus, best seen with slit lamp examination.

questions.text: A 42-year-old female patient presents with acute onset redness of the left eye, diminution of vision, and severe headache. She has no history of similar complaints in the past. On examination, the pupil is vertically oval and mid-dilated, along with a shallow anterior chamber and, IOP of 40 mm Hg. What is the management of the condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above The given scenario depicts acute congestive glaucoma, which needs to be treated with topical and systemic medications. Raised IOP is controlled immediately with intravenous acetazolamide. Option A. 500 mg, and/or intravenous mannitol. These measures also relieve ischaemic changes in the iris and lead to a decrease in corneal oedema. Topical pilocarpine 2% should be instituted to constrict the pupil and pull the iris away from the angle. Option B. After the control of intraocular pressure, a laser iridotomy is mandatory in the affected eyes and also prophylactically in the unaffected eye. Option C. In the procedure of peripheral laser iridotomy, a hole is made in the periphery of the iris, allowing the aqueous to drain directly from the posterior chamber into the region of the trabecular meshwork.
